description: From Middle English reclaymen, recleymen, reclamen, from Anglo-Norman reclamer (noun reclaim and Middle French reclamer (noun reclaim), from Latin reclāmō, reclāmāre.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, falconry) The calling back of a hawk.
(obsolete) The bringing back or recalling of a person; the fetching of someone back.
An effort to take something back, to reclaim something.

verbs.description: reclaim (third-person singular simple present reclaims, present participle reclaiming, simple past and past participle reclaimed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To return land to a suitable condition for use.
(transitive) To obtain useful products from waste; to recycle.
(transitive) To claim something back; to repossess.
(transitive, dated) To return someone to a proper course of action, or correct an error; to reform.
examples: Your errour, in time reclaimed, will be veniall.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To tame or domesticate a wild animal.
(transitive, archaic) To call back from flight or disorderly action; to call to, for the purpose of subduing or quieting.
examples: They were the head-strong horses, who hurried Octavius  […]  along, and were deaf to his reclaiming them.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To cry out in opposition or contradiction; to exclaim against anything; to contradict; to take exceptions.
examples: Scripture reclaims, and the whole Catholic church reclaims, and Christian ears would not bear it.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) To draw back; to give way.
(intransitive, law, Scotland) To appeal from the Lord Ordinary to the inner house of the Court of Session.
(sociology) To bring back a term into acceptable usage, usually of a slur, and usually by the group that was once targeted by that slur.
examples: Once a term of homophobic abuse, the term “queer” has been reclaimed as a marker for some gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender (GLBT), and other marginalized sexual identities.
